title: Authors and Citation
text: McDonald D (2022). suffpcr: Sufficient Principal Component Regression. R package version 0.1.0, https://dajmcdon.github.io/suffpcr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {suffpcr: Sufficient Principal Component Regression},   author = {Daniel J. McDonald},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://dajmcdon.github.io/suffpcr/}, }

title: Sufficient Principal Component Regression
text: goal suffpcr estimate sufficient principal component regression implementing row-sparse PCA followed ordinary least squares logistic regression.

title: Sufficient Principal Component Regression
text: can install package

title: Sufficient Principal Component Regression
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(suffpcr) n <- 100 p <- 50 U <- rnorm(n) V <- c(rnorm(5), rep(0, p - 5)) V <- V / sqrt(sum(V^2)) bstar <- V * (5 / (5.1)) X <- 5 * tcrossprod(U, V) + 0.1 * matrix(rnorm(n * p), n) y <- U + rnorm(n) out <- suffPCR(X, y, d=1:3)

title: Gene expression and survival data for acute myeloid leukemia — aml

title: Gene expression and survival data for acute myeloid leukemia — aml
text: L Bullinger et al. Gene expression profiling identifies new subclasses improves outcome prediction adult myeloid leukemia. New England Journal Medicine, 350(16):1605–1616, 2004.

text: Method returning predictions fitted suffpcr object

title: Method for returning predictions of a fitted suffpcr object — predict.suffpcr
code: # S3 method for suffpcr predict(   object,   newdata = NULL,   type = c("link", "response"),   i = NULL,   d = NULL,   ... )

title: Method for returning predictions of a fitted suffpcr object — predict.suffpcr
text: object suffpcr object, created suffpcr() newdata optionally, matrix variables predict. omitted, fitted linear predictors used. type type prediction required. default scale linear predictors; alternative "response" scale response variable. Thus default binomial model default predictions log-odds (probabilities logit scale) type = "response" gives predicted probabilities. optional vector lambda indices retrieve d optional vector d indices retrieve ... ignored

title: Method for returning predictions of a fitted suffpcr object — predict.suffpcr
text: matrix (vector) predicted values. column corresponds one lambda x d estimate

title: Sufficient principal component regression — suffpcr
text: Estimates principal component regression (classification) assumption loadings row-sparse. assumption valid, resulting predictors guaranteed irrelevant predicting response variable. results sparse model sparse linear combinations features used final prediction

title: Sufficient principal component regression — suffpcr
code: suffpcr(   X,   Y,   family = c("gaussian", "binomial"),   d = 3,   n_lambda = 10,   maxnvar = ncol(X),   lambda = NULL,   lambda_max = NULL,   lambda_min = NULL,   lambda_seq = c("loglinear", "linear"),   screening = TRUE )

title: Sufficient principal component regression — suffpcr
text: See Github vqv/fps original (non-approximate) implementation fps upon based along paper Fantope Projection Selection (NeurIPS 2013).

title: Sufficient principal component regression — suffpcr
text: X n p matrix features Y length n response family optional family argument implement regression ("gaussian", default) classification ("binomial") d target PC dimension n_lambda number different lambda solutions examine maxnvar optional limit number variables consider lambda optional vector lambda values use penalty lambda_max optional largest value lambda lambda_min optional smallest value lambda, must non-negative less lambda_max lambda_seq lambda constructed loglinear linear scale minimum maximum screening screen algorithm 2

title: Sufficient principal component regression — suffpcr
text: object class "suffPCR" containing estimated coefficients, lambda values, norms Vhat number additional components. predict() coef() methods available accessing.

title: Sufficient principal component regression — suffpcr
code: n <- 100 p <- 50 U <- rnorm(n) V <- c(rnorm(5), rep(0, p - 5)) V <- V / sqrt(sum(V^2)) bstar <- V * (5 / (5.1)) X <- 5 * tcrossprod(U, V) + 0.1 * matrix(rnorm(n * p), n) y <- U + rnorm(n) out <- suffpcr(X, y, d = 1:3)
